contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are repeated to emphasize how strongly their enemies are against them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: our enemies ... all who hate us

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Make ready the way of the Lord ... make his paths straight

contextId.information: This means the same thing as the first part of the sentence in order to emphasize its truth. It can also be stated in active form. AT: "people will learn about everything that others try to hide" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: nothing hidden that will not be known

contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings, which Jesus used to emphasize his point. Some languages have different ways of emphasizing. AT: "they should always keep on praying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: they should always pray, and not become discouraged

contextId.information: These two sentences have similar meaning and they are combined for emphasis. Some languages emphasize in a different way. AT: "You must certainly allow the children to come to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Permit the little children to come to me, and do not forbid them

contextId.information: These two sentences have similar meaning said twice for emphasis. Some languages have different ways of showing emphasis. AT: "the Lord is the God of living people only" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: he is not the God of the dead, but of the living
